Patriot

Since this thread is really a continuation of the death penalty one in religion, I'll start by posting my latest reply. I'll assume that my readers are up-to-date as to what we all have been saying in the other debate, cause otherwise your gonna get kinda lost. 
 
 So. 
 
 Since I posted last quite a few things have happened: 
 
 Falling, no, we cannot be executed for our thoughts. That is not the realm of the civil government. I'm sure you wouldn't suggest that the Old Testament laws were to be utilized in that way, cause they were not. 
 As for my twisted idea of mercy... umm isn't it better to be a slave than to be dead? It's better than accepting the surrender and then killing them which has happened before. 
 I cannot see how I'm giving Christianity a bad name! Because I state what I believe? What if I think you are giving us a bad name? 
 
 Now thistown:
 I'll choose to ignore your first comment. 
 
 Deuteronomy 23:2 
 "Yes I suppose that death by stoning would be a pretty good incentive. but no one in their right mind would impose a law like this, no Christian at least."
 
 Uh huh, a very good incentive. I don't know why you think you cannot be in your right mind to impose this law! If you believe the whole Bible, you actually have no choice. 
 
 Deuteronomy 21:18 
 "Umm...I missed something, I read 3 different translations and none mention witchcraft. They mention laziness and drunkenness, but nothing of sorcery."
 
 Sorry, my mistake. The verse is 1 Samuel 15:23. I neglected to include the citation. :D
 
 Deuteronomy 20:11 
 This is not mercy...when someone surrenders you do not take them as your slave, take their women and children into bondage. Any nation present day who enslaved an entire culture in this manner would be seen on the same level as the Nazis. And I love how you use "tributary" instead of slave, makes it sound much more...."merciful".
 
 Why don't you take them as your slave? What do you do with them? Say, great, have a good day? Why do you think you are attacking them in the first place? Maybe cause they've done something to you? Remember, this is single cities, not entire nations that we are talking about here. 
 Thx for your compliment about me using "tributary" instead of "slave" that's what it means in Hebrew. 
 
 Exodus 20:21
 Pretty much just gave up on this one huh? Yes they will have to answer to God, but remember these were laws given to the governing body by God so....irrelevant.
 
 I guess I don't understand your point here... irrelevant? The idea is if the slave lives for a while before dying, the civil government must assume that he died of other causes.

post_info.post_title: Validity and Application of Old Testament Laws

Patriot

I'm sorry you are growing weary of "restating" your position, maybe if you'd find some other evidence we'd be able to move on. I do not know what you are trying to say, I've taken everything you've said at face value. 
 
 "You obviously (I hope) don't believe that some of these should become United States laws, but you believe that the one that you agree with should be. I am simply pointing out that your are selectively manipulating that which is "the solemn and eternal word of God" and the rest is...well you haven't addressed the rest yet, you've only avoided the issue by stating that I said "cut off penis" instead of circumcision and stating what the laws were designed to discourage."
 
 I don't believe they should become United States laws. They should be enacted at the state level. I am not "selectively manipulating" God's Word.... I've given a defense for every verse! How many times must I say it! I BELIEVE THE WHOLE BIBLE!!!!!!! What parts am I ignoring? I didn't ignore your Matthew 5 verses... I provided a rebuttal! I faithfully have answered every verse you've given me. It's very unfair of you to then accuse me of selectively applying the Word of God. 
 As to your last sentence, I have nothing to do with that, it was calligirl. I don't care what your version says that is different from what my version says, it all ends up the same in the end. 
 
 "So here is my question, and for everyone's sake it's not a hard question, it's just a scary one to you. Why should the death penalty law from God carry over and the stone your child for being a fat, lazy drunk not? Why should the death penalty carry over and the death to all adulterers, or the law that the US must take all of any country we invade into slavery, or the no former pagans in the church laws, not apply? We can't have one without the other, in fact we can't have one without all of them. These laws come in a package, if you claim that they are the Laws of God (which I agree they are) and that Jesus's life and death didn't change them (which I think it did) then you have to believe that each and every one of them should be instated in the US law. Is that not perfectly clear? You can't call for the death penalty under God and ignore the rest."
 
 It's not hard or scary. My answer is: Why shouldn't the law of God carry over? I think all those things should be implemented. I have to study it further to see exactly how they will be implemented, but I think they should. So, is that not the answer you were looking for? THEY DO APPLY. Guess I didn't make that clear. 
 
 "And Patriot, you're stooping. Stop trying to demonize me into some Old Testament hating pagan just because you've run out of things to say. It doesn't make you look better, I promise."
 
 Well thistown, all I did was quote you....
 
 "You know full well that I don't believe that the Old Testament laws are "ridiculous", 
 
 Falling said that some of the o.t. laws were "ridiculous" so that wasn't aimed at you.
 
 "you would like to believe that I did, because then you could simply dismiss my arguments. But I believe in the laws of the Old Testament, I believe they were from God. But I believe that a man named Jesus took them all and made them into two, "Love the Lord with all your heart", "And love your neighbor as yourself." I think that he is the reason that we don't stone our children anymore, or eliminate or enslave (if they're lucky) entire cultures and civilizations, or still believe in taking the life of a man as property (for 7 years or whatever, it is against his will and it is without pay=slavery). These are not the laws of Jesus Christ, they are not a part of the new covenant...but you obviously believe that one of them is a part, unfortunately my friend you can't just take one. If it applies they all do. Simple as that."
 
 
 I'll take them all thx. :D Since this is now an Old Testament law debate, I'll take your last statement about "taking the life of a man as property (for 7 years or whatever, it is against his will and it is without pay=slavery)." If that's what you think slavery is, yes, it's slavery. So what. It will interest you to know that involuntary servitude, as a punishment, is still legal in the US, if you read the 13th Amendment. I think that's a good law. Say you steal something. You get caught. You are unable to restore it 2-4 times what you stole to the person you wronged (another OT law)... should you sit in prison? NO! you should work. Even if it's against your will. I think that's a good law. 
 I don't think that the laws Jesus gave us as individuals interfere with the execution of justice. 
 
 One more word on the death penalty... for any of the crimes in the Old Testament that carried the death penalty, there had to be 2-3 witnesses. (Deuteronomy 17:6) For many of the crimes, it's unlikely that the culprits will be caught UNLESS they are doing it openly. 
 
 Also, I'd like to bring up.... Something I said a while ago. About how if the government was run on the rule of "turn the other cheek" we'd have anarchy. 
 What I mean is, if that's the rule for government, we have no government. Sure, you can have legislatures, you can have courts, but they are unenforceable. Cause the rule is to "turn the other cheek." Any kind of punishment is then illegitimate (fines aren't turning the other cheek, neither are jail sentances.) I don't know, maybe that's what you are saying. I just wanted to clarify that statement. 
 As a matter of interest, falling, thistown, and others, what, in your opinion, SHOULD happen to murderers?
 
 The rest of the debate was on John 8:1-9. 
 Who brought this woman to Jesus? The Pharisees. They were RELIGIOUS government. The religious government has no authority to take away life. 
 Keeping that in mind, we also notice they are trying to trap Christ here. (verse 6). If Christ rules one way or the other, they are going to nail him. You will notice that when the question is first posed, Christ ignores it, and they have to repeat themselves for a while before He finally answers them. 
 When he does answer, He doesn't say that what they say should happen to her is wrong or unjust. He just tells them, "He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her." One by one, her accusers leave. Christ declined to giver her the death penalty because a) it was none of His business. He didn't come to rule Israel in the civil realm, as many expected the Messiah would do. His kingdom was not of this world. Therefore, He had little to do with the civil government, something that is wholly of this world. B) She was forgiven because she was repentant (obviously) and Jesus had the power to forgive her sins. However, he warned her to "sin no more." 
 
 Finally, Tim asks (Equity, but I'll answer too): 
 
 "In Matthew 12 the pharisees caught the disciples of Jesus breaking the Sabbath Day. You know what the punishment for breaking the Sabbath Day was? It was the death penalty according to the Old Testament (Numbers 15:32-36). So why didn't Jesus want his disciples to be put to death? Do you really think that Jesus favored the death penalty?
 
 First of all, the example in Numbers is a one time deal... God didn't say that this was to be a general rule, I think He ordered this execution to show He was serious about this. 
 Second, Jesus can do what he wants. His answer (ultimately) to the Pharisees was, "For the Son of man is Lord even of the sabbath day." (vs. 8.) I seem to recall other exceptions to the sabbath rule... like the ox in the ditch. If your ox fell into a ditch on the sabbath, you were allowed to go and get him out. You were also permitted to go a certain distance on the sabbath. The spirit of the law is more important than the words of the law. (Original intent strikes again!!!) This rule is actually found in this chapter, verse 11. Deuteronomy 22:4 provides what must have been the basis for this law. 
 
 Ok. Last but not least. I know we all agree on abortion (at least falling does). Why is abortion wrong?
Tim

As I understand, Jesus fulfilled the law of Moses. Therefore, the law of Moses ended with Jesus. I think that both Paul and Jesus make this very clear in the New Testament. So you think our society would be ideal if it were governed by Old Testament Laws? Do you actually approve of the death penalty in the following cases? The Old Testament said people in the following categories deserve the death penalty:
 
 People who curse their father or mother (Leviticus 20:9)
 People who engage in witchcraft and sorcery (Leviticus 20:27)
 People who blaspheme the name of the Lord (Leviticus 24:16)
 People who do work on the Sabbath (Exodus 31:12-15)
 People who worship idols (Deuteronomy 17:2-5)
 Prophets who make false prophecies (Deuteronomy 18:20-22)
 People who disobey or don't listen to their parents 
 (Deuteronomy 21:18-21)
 
 People who rape girls who are betrothed to someone (if the girl is not promised to someone, then the rapist must marry his victim) (Deuteronomy 22:23-29)
 
 Rape victims who are betrothed to someone and live in the city must die (Rape victims who live in the country escape the death penalty) (Deuteronomy 22:23-29)
mazet

I've only sort of skimmed the page, but had something I thought was a bit relevant:
 
 In Jewish tradition (the old testament) there are many things which are said to be punishable by death, but, here's some more information about that is interesting (read at least the first 2 paragraphs):
 
 http://www.jewishjournal.com/old/deathpenalty2.3.10.0.htm
thistownwilleat

Whoa. I had no idea you were this much of an extremist. If you believe that we should put EVERY SINGLE old testament law into effect then I can say nothing to you. Except that I would really, seriously take a good, hard, long look at who you find Jesus Christ to be. Because I find a man of love, compassion, mercy, and forgiveness...who was more about freedom than the rules. I think he changed things from how they were. 
 
 I'm tired of arguing, and I honestly believe everything I say to be useless if you honestly believe that a girl who has premarital sex should be dragged in fron of her own father, and stoned. This is not the gospel.
thistownwilleat

I'm interested to know if Calligirl believes that every law of the Old Testament should be followed to the letter in present day?
 
 I've never met anyone else besides Patriot and I want to see if this is more common than I had thought it to be.,
Patriot

For the record, I'd like to note that there are some laws in the Old Testament that were changed/abolished when Jesus came. Specifically those dealing with animal sacrifice and the temple. Individuals can now approach God themselves, they don't need a priest. 
 
 Tim:
 
 Jesus didn't come to abolish the law, but to make it complete (fulfilled). (Matthew 5:17-19)
 
 I've run through most of those laws already w/ thistown except for the one you mention about being killed for breaking the Sabbath. That was a one time thing, God didn't give an indication that that was to be the general rule. 
 
 As for the other rules, keep in mind that there must be 2-3 witnesses to the act before the person can be executed. If we adopted this policy today, there would be a whole lot less executions period. (I'd assume.)
 
 But thistown, I'm interested, what do you suggest we do with murderers? Now that I've stated my position rather starkly, I'd like to look at your side.
thistownwilleat

I say that we lock them up. Danger to society is negated (just like with the death penalty), justice is served at less financially than the death penalty, and at half the moral controversy and dillemma. We are to flawed of a people to be trusted with the life of a person.
Patriot

I see. Life imprisonment. That has always made me uneasy.. having all these people with absolutely nothing to lose if they do something wrong... like escape. I think that guards are authorized to shoot such persons though. But perhaps that's just me, i have no statistics or anything. i have an acquaintance who's a prison guard and to hear him talk! Not a nice place to work. 
 
 I didn't realize that the death penalty was more expensive... I can get a .30-06 bullet for around 30 cents a round. I don't think it costs much more (per person) for a rope, or an electric shock. Lethal injection is bound to be more expensive. Nevertheless, it seems to me life imprisonment is slightly more expensive than that. Perhaps you'd bring that up in the secular death penalty thread? 
 
 Ok. One more question. Should the government be run on the rule of "turning the other cheek"?
 
 hehe i guess i should say now that I'm against prison as a punishment. :D
fallingupwards

even if the death penalty was cheaper, that does not give us authorization to just execute people left and right. put them in prisons. security is very tight in prisons, it would be impossible for them to escape.
Patriot

That's very true falling, but I was interested in how thistown could claim that life imprisonment was cheaper. 
 
 I suppose it'd be ok for the guards in those high security prisons to shoot escaping prisoners?
mazet

Originally posted by Patriot 
 That's very true falling, but I was interested in how thistown could claim that life imprisonment was cheaper. 
 
 I suppose it'd be ok for the guards in those high security prisons to shoot escaping prisoners? 
 
 
 Oh, jeez...
 
 Ok, It goes a bit like this:
 
 Many many appeals. More expensive prison to keep people on death row at. Expensive leathal injection. It comes out to over twice as much. And this isn't just some odd statistic, it's agreed upon by just about everyone (although not brought up by the pro-death penalty side very often)
Patriot

I see i have some death penalty questions. Please look for them in the secular death penalty thread. 
 
 thx
Calligirl

Tim:
 Why don't you take the time to read your Bible?! Have you ever read this verse? Matthew 5:17-20 "Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them. 18I tell you the truth, until heaven and earth disappear, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until everything is accomplished. 19Anyone who breaks one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do the same will be called least in the kingdom of heaven, but whoever practices and teaches these commands will be called great in the kingdom of heaven. 20For I tell you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the Pharisees and the teachers of the law, you will certainly not enter the kingdom of heaven." Try again.
 
 Thistownwilleatu: 
 "I'm interested to know if Calligirl believes that every law of the Old Testament should be followed to the letter in present day?"
 
 If it means people will be deterred from doing wrong according to Biblical standards, in some ways yes I do. I don't agree with stoning, though. That's just plain torture.
Tim

Calligirl,
 I am very familiar with that verse. Read it more carefully. It says that the law would not pass away until all has been accomplished.
 Jesus has now accomplished everything, so the law (of Moses) has passed away. 
 
 Paul explained this:
 "When you were dead in your sins and in the uncircumcision of your sinful nature, God made you alive with Christ. He forgave us all our sins, having canceled the written code, with its regulations, that was against us and that stood opposed to us; he took it away, nailing it to the cross."
 (Col. 2:14)
 
 The Law of Moses was taken away and nailed to the cross.
fallingupwards
calli, if u do not believe in stoning then you do not believe that the old laws should be used today
thistownwilleat
Fallingupwards is right, if you actually believe that these should be in place today then they are not open to individual interpretation...they have to be followed to the letter.
Patriot

Thistown, you never answered my question:
 
 do you think that the government should be run on the "turn the other cheek" principle?
Calligirl

Tim:
 
 "I am very familiar with that verse. Read it more carefully. It says that the law would not pass away until all has been accomplished. Jesus has now accomplished everything, so the law (of Moses) has passed away."
 
 That explanation sounds valid...until you take a closer look. "UNTIL HEAVEN AND EARTH DISSAPEAR, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until everything is accomplished." Jesus is not talking about His death and resurrection, he is talking about when life on this earth as we know it ceases to exist. (Read Revelations.)
 
 "The Law of Moses was taken away and nailed to the cross."
 
 Wrong interpretation here too. Read the verse more closely "having canceled the written code, with its regulations, that was against us and that stood opposed to us; he took it away, nailing it to the cross." What this verse is talking about is the previous need for SACRIFICES. When Jesus died on the cross, he became the ultimate sacrifice so that we wouldn't have to sacrifice animals for our sins anymore. THAT was the law that he took away and nailed on the cross. Not the "law of Moses".
Tim

According to your interpretation of those verses we could conclude that we still need animal sacrifices because Heaven and Earth have not passed away yet. "not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law" would include sacrifices. That would also include stoning.
Calligirl

The "written code, with its regulations, that was AGAINST US and that STOOD APPOSED to us" was the law about animal sacrifice. It prevented people from being able to be completely sin free without the use of sacrifices. That law was gotten rid of when Christ became the ultimate sacrifice. The "Law of Moses" said nothing about sacrifices. It set the disciplinary guidlines for the people.
Tim

Jesus said he came to fulfill the law. I think Jesus was saying that until Heaven and Earth dissapear, no unfulfilled law would pass away. Laws that Jesus fulfilled could pass away.
 
 What evidence do you have that Paul was only talking about animal sacrifices? It's interesting that you say that animal sacrifices are not part of the Law of Moses. It was Moses himself who instructed the Israelites concerning animal sacrifices in the Old Testament.
Calligirl

Don't use the words "I think" in a debate. That is your personal opinion, not necessarily what the Bible says. Jesus "fulfilled" the need for animal sacrifices. He did not "fulfill" the law for murder, rape, theft, etc. Read from Deuteronomy 20 to the end of the book.
Tim

Why only read from Deuteronomy 20 to the end of the book? Why not read all five books of Moses- Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy. You like to pick and choose what you read. You need to look at the whole picture if you want to understand the Law of Moses. One of the most important parts of the Law of Moses (the ten commandments) is found in Exodus 20.
Calligirl

Okay, maybe you're not understanding me. Jeus came as a sacrifice to fulfill the need for all sacrifices. If you can give me one verse which says that after Christ came and died on the cross for us, all forms of punishment for doing wrong went away then I'll debate with you. Until then it's not worth it 'cause we are stuck in a rut with this debate on what Christ "really meant".
fallingupwards
so then you believe we should stone those who break the law
Calligirl
No, I don't believe we should stone those who break the law. I do believe that those who break the law should be punished.
fallingupwards

but you said that the forms of punishment were not done away with when Christ died for us. therefore, according to you, stoning is still acceptable as a form of punishment because Christ did not do away with the forms of punishment, according to you.
thistownwilleat

Do you not see your own contradictions...you say that the old testament laws should be reinstated because they are the supreme law of God, but should be altered because you apparently find them "flawed".
Patriot

Thistown, you aren't ignoring me are you? :D
 
 do you think that the government should be run on the "turn the other cheek" principle? Cause that was your main objection to the death penalty as I recall.
fallingupwards
patriot, thats like saying "should the government be run on a principle that Jesus taught us?"
Patriot

true, but remember i said that there were different rules for us and the civil government? I'll ask you too. You think we should run the government on the "turn the other cheek" principle? I believe in a God of order, and to take "turn the other cheek" to the extreme in government would NOT create order.
XYOU

sure outdated and some are non sense !
 
 As man feel horny when see sexy woman is said to be illegal accoding to 10 commandments. ( That's God created us man like that )
Patriot
XYOU, if you look at the Bible you will see that it is not wrong to be tempted, (Jesus was tempted) but it is wrong to give in to that temptation.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Validity and Application of Old Testament Laws
